projects.name: One Music
projects.description: Move over, Spotify - I've created my own clone of your popular music streaming service using TypeScript! With my Spotify Clone, users can access their own Spotify account, search for their favorite tracks and albums, and even listen to short previews of songs. And let's not forget about the slick and stylish interface, which I personally think is cooler than a polar bear's toenails. As a first-time TypeScript user, I was thrilled to learn how to incorporate strong typing and other advanced features into my code. Now, I'm ready to rock and roll (or hip-hop and chill) with my very own Spotify Clone. Who knows, maybe Spotify will be knocking on my door for a job offer soon!

projects.name: Heroes panel
projects.description: I recently embarked on a new web development adventure and created a React-based application called the Hero Panel. This app lets users create their own superheroes with unique abilities, including water, air, earth, and fire. As a first-time React user, I was thrilled to learn how to use this powerful library to build a dynamic and responsive user interface. With the Hero Panel, users can easily add and remove heroes, customize their abilities, and save their creations for future battles against evil villains. Overall, this project was a super fun way to flex my coding muscles and unleash my inner superhero nerd. It's time to save the world, one line of code at a time!

projects.name: Pig game
projects.description: I built the ultimate digital Pig Game experience using JavaScript, because sometimes you just need a break from adulting and want to roll some virtual dice. Through this project, I learned how to code the logic for the game, handle user input, and manipulate the DOM like a pro. Now, I can confidently say that I am a master of pig-based gaming and a web development wizard. Plus, who needs friends to play when you have a computer and a love for swine-themed games?

projects.name: Guess number
projects.description: Test your luck and guessing skills with this fun, browser-based game. In this game, the computer selects a random number between 1 and 100, and the player tries to guess the number in as few attempts as possible. The game features a user-friendly interface, where the player inputs their guess, and the computer responds with a message indicating whether the guess is too high, too low, or correct. The player continues guessing until they correctly guess the number, at which point they can choose to play again or exit the game. This implementation uses vanilla JavaScript, HTML, and CSS to create a lightweight, yet engaging game experience. Enjoy the challenge of guessing the number and try to beat your high score!

projects.name: E-commerce
projects.description: Move over, ASOS - I've created a near-full clone of your online shopping platform using some of the hottest web development tools around. With my ASOS Clone, users can browse a wide variety of products, add items to their cart, and check out like a boss. Although the search function is currently limited due to API constraints, I still got to flex my coding muscles with some of the latest and greatest tech, including Redux Toolkit, Next.js, Prisma, and Next Auth for secure user authentication. As a first-time user of these tools, I was excited to learn how to integrate them into my project and take my skills to the next level. While I don't necessarily expect a call from ASOS anytime soon, creating a near-full clone of their online shopping platform using the latest web development tools was still an exciting and rewarding experience. The intersection of fashion and tech has never been more exciting!

Enjoy the popular 2048 puzzle game in a pure JavaScript implementation without external libraries. Slide numbered tiles on a two-dimensional grid to combine them and create a tile with the number 2048. This minimalist game features smooth animations and a simple user interface.
